item.title: NASA Moon Launch Delay: What to Know About the Artemis Rocket
item.description: The mission’s managers will complete assessments before announcing whether the rocket could try to launch again this weekend.
item.dc:creator: Kenneth Chang and Christine Chung
item.media:credit: Brynn Anderson/Associated Press
item.media:description: The Artemis I mission on the launchpad at Kennedy Space Center, at sunrise on Monday.

item.title: Trump Request for Special Master Could Open Door for Delays to Investigation
item.description: The former president, who used the slow pace of litigation to run out the clock on congressional oversight, is seeking intervention that could lead to appeals and slow the documents inquiry.
item.dc:creator: Charlie Savage, Glenn Thrush and Alan Feuer
item.media:credit: Leigh Vogel for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Justice Department said in a court filing that it had completed a detailed analysis of all the documents retrieved from former President Donald J. Trump’s Florida residence, Mar-a-Lago.

item.title: Lindsey Graham Predicts ‘Riots in the Streets’ if Trump Is Prosecuted
item.description: Senator Lindsey Graham drew a comparison between the investigation of former President Donald J. Trump and a decision not to prosecute Hillary Clinton over using a private server.
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Weisman
item.media:credit: Michael A. McCoy for The New York Times
item.media:description: Senator Lindsey Graham of South Carolina has moved from a fierce critic of former President Donald J. Trump to a loyal companion.

item.title: Ukraine Announces Offensive in Kherson, as Inspectors Head to Nuclear Plant
item.description: The scale of Ukraine’s push in the Kherson region was unclear, but it has vowed for months to mount a counteroffensive to retake territory seized by Russia.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer
item.media:credit: Jim Huylebroek for The New York Times
item.media:description: Soldiers of Ukraine’s Territorial Defense Forces at a frontline position near Bakhmut, in the eastern Donetsk region, on Monday.

item.title: The First Shipment of Iranian Military Drones Arrives in Russia
item.description: Russia could deploy the drones in its war against Ukraine to conduct air-to-surface attacks, carry out electronic warfare and identify targets, according to U.S. officials.
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi and Julian E. Barnes
item.media:credit: Iranian Army, via Associated Press
item.media:description: In this photo released by the Iranian Army on Thursday, a drone is launched as part of a military drill in Iran.

item.title: These Celebrities and Politicians Came Out to See Serena Williams
item.description: As well as Martina Navratilova, Mike Tyson, Katie Couric, Matt Damon, Spike Lee, Lindsey Vonn and Dr. Ruth Westheimer.
item.dc:creator: Jesus Jiménez
item.media:credit: Mike Segar/Reuters
item.media:description: Anna Wintour, top center, the editor of Vogue, and Oracene Price, at center, Serena Williams’s mother, were among the guests in Williams’s player’s box.

item.title: Serena Williams is driving the most expensive U.S. Open tickets in years.
item.dc:creator: Jesus Jiménez
item.media:credit: Gabriela Bhaskar for The New York Times
item.media:description: Standing on Monday for the national anthem at Louis Armstrong Stadium.

item.title: Clashes in Baghdad Intensify Amid Political Chaos in Iraq
item.description: The renewed violence has set Iraq on edge, with many fearing another destabilized phase after two decades of almost constant fighting.
item.dc:creator: Jane Arraf
item.media:credit: Ahmad Al-Rubaye/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Armed members of Muqtada al-Sadr’s paramilitary organization during clashes with pro-Iranian Iraqi security forces in Baghdad’s Green Zone on Tuesday.

item.title: Deadly Floods Devastate an Already Fragile Pakistan
item.description: More than 1,100 have died as record monsoon rains inundate the country, washing away bridges, roads and crop fields. Much of Pakistan is underwater.
item.dc:creator: Max Bearak, Raymond Zhong and Ihsanullah Tipu Mehsud
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:credit: Asim Tanveer/Associated Press
item.media:description: Army troops evacuated people from a flood-hit area in Rajanpur, Punjab district, Pakistan, on Saturday.

item.title: In Brazil, the Last Member of an Isolated Indigenous Tribe Dies
item.description: Known as the “Man of the Hole,” the last member of an Indigenous group was found dead this month, marking the first recorded disappearance of an isolated tribe in the country.
item.dc:creator: Flávia Milhorance and André Spigariol
item.media:credit: Funai/EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: A still image from a video provided by the Brazilian government showing one of the huts built by the “Man of the Hole” in Rondônia State in 2018.

item.title: As Rome Burns (or at Least Its Garbage), a Mayor Dares to Dream
item.description: Could a solution to Rome’s perpetual trash crisis really be in sight? Mayor Roberto Gualtieri would like to think so.
item.dc:creator: Jason Horowitz
item.media:credit: Alessandro Penso for The New York Times
item.media:description: A worker at a junkyard in Rome searched for his dog, which had been missing since the lot caught fire last month, one of a rash of such blazes across the city.

item.title: San Francisco’s Art Market Struggles in the Shadow of Los Angeles
item.description: Though some small galleries are opening or expanding, the mega dealers have closed shop, a blow to an area with a vibrant artistic history.
item.dc:creator: Adam Nagourney and Robin Pogrebin
item.category: Institute of Contemporary Art San Francisco
item.media:credit: Ulysses Ortega for The New York Times

item.title: An Orlando Museum’s Disputed Basquiats Are Gone. Its Leadership Is, Too.
item.description: In the wake of an F.B.I. raid, the crisis at the Orlando Museum of Art deepened amid upheaval on its board and the resignation of its interim director.
item.dc:creator: Brett Sokol
item.media:credit: Zack Wittman for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Orlando Museum of Art is facing a crisis, with five board members ousted and an interim director who resigned suddenly.

item.title: Foreign Films, English Titles and the Dilemma Distributors Face
item.description: Leave as is? Translate? Change altogether? A movie’s success doesn’t depend entirely on what we call it, but it can have a big effect.
item.dc:creator: Nicolas Rapold

item.title: Why I Changed My Mind on Student Debt Forgiveness
item.description: Our current system of student loans and college funding is at odds with what we hope to achieve by encouraging people to go to college.
item.dc:creator: Susan Dynarski
item.media:credit: Illustration by Sam Whitney/The New York Times; image by Nay Ni Ratn Mak Can Thuk/EyeEm, via Getty Images

item.title: What It’s Like to Have Face Blindness
item.description: When you can’t rely on facial recognition, you look beyond the obvious.
item.dc:creator: James Robinson

item.title: What Bill Barr Did to Clear Trump Is Still a Danger
item.description: The ability to investigate future high-level wrongdoing in the executive branch is at stake.
item.dc:creator: Neal K. Katyal
item.media:credit: Doug Mills/The New York Times
item.media:description: Donald Trump and Attorney General Bill Barr in 2019.

item.title: Ted Cruz Would Like to Put Some Words in Your Mouth
item.description: The idea that student loan relief is a handout to a small minority of affluent college graduates is simply a myth.
item.dc:creator: Jamelle Bouie
item.media:credit: Travis Dove for The New York Times

item.title: I’m a Ukrainian Soldier, and I’ve Accepted My Death
item.description: So it must be for those who tread the path of war.
item.dc:creator: Artem Chekh
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times
item.media:description: A mass burial in Bucha, Ukraine, this month.

item.title: The Book That Explains Our Cultural Stagnation
item.description: Art has gotten so boring. W. David Marx knows why.
item.dc:creator: Michelle Goldberg
item.category: Status and Culture: How Our Desire for Social Rank Creates Taste, Identity, Art, Fashion, and Constant Change (Book)
item.media:credit: Calla Kessler for The New York Times
item.media:description: Partygoers at Art Basel Miami Beach.

item.title: A Grammy-Nominated Singer Performs and Explores Music’s Deep Power Over Us
item.description: Allison Russell discusses — and demonstrates — the craft of songwriting, and how to find ‘survivor’s joy’ and kinship through music.
item.dc:creator: ‘The Ezra Klein Show’
item.media:credit: Marc Baptiste

item.title: Donald Trump’s Death Grip Has Upended the G.O.P. Senate Map
item.description: Republicans seem to feel less feisty than when they were cruising into the summer.
item.dc:creator: Michelle Cottle
item.media:credit: Damon Winter/The New York Times

item.title: How Will the Student Loan Forgiveness Plan Affect You?
item.description: We want to hear about what President Biden’s debt cancellation plan means for your life and finances.
item.dc:creator: Lora Kelley
item.media:credit: Kendrick Brinson for The New York Times

item.title: Rage Against the Machine, Roaring On
item.description: A conversation about the band’s return, its evolving message and the nature of comeback tours.
item.media:credit: Jamie Kelter Davis for The New York Times

item.title: In Track and Field, Money Flows to the Flashy and Stylish
item.description: Winning is important when it comes to making a living in the sport. But so is finishing in style.
item.dc:creator: Kris Rhim
item.media:credit: Kai Pfaffenbach/Reuters
item.media:description: Usain Bolt of Jamaica smiles while winning the 100-meter semifinal sprint at the 2016 Olympics in Rio de Janeiro.

item.title: Are You Ready for Your Fall Booster?
item.description: Tell us about it.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times

item.title: Biden to Focus on ‘Battle for the Soul of the Nation’ in Prime-Time Speech
item.description: The president is set to return to his campaign theme of democracy in peril as his party fights to retain its hold on Congress in the midterm elections.
item.dc:creator: Zolan Kanno-Youngs
item.media:credit: Pete Marovich for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Biden’s speech is also expected to emphasize the reputation of the United States on the global stage.

item.title: Pastor Matt Chandler Steps Aside After ‘Unwise’ Online Relationship
item.description: Matt Chandler’s leave of absence from the Village Church near Dallas comes as Southern Baptists are already facing challenges.
item.dc:creator: Elizabeth Dias and Ruth Graham
item.media:credit: Ryan Longnecker
item.media:description: Matt Chandler has been the head pastor of the Village Church for about 20 years.

item.title: California Senate Passes Bill to Regulate Fast-Food Industry
item.description: If signed by Gov. Gavin Newsom, the measure would create a state council to establish minimum pay and safety conditions on an industrywide basis.
item.dc:creator: Noam Scheiber
item.media:credit: Rich Pedroncelli/Associated Press
item.media:description: Supporters of a bill that would regulate working conditions in the fast-food industry marched in Sacramento this month.

item.title: Tomatoes Spill Onto Interstate, Causing Crashes, Quips and Confusion
item.description: A crash involving a big-rig truck caused 150,000 tomatoes to scatter across Interstate 80 in Vacaville, Calif. Passing vehicles ground them into a slippery red pulp.
item.dc:creator: Eduardo Medina
item.media:credit: CHP SOLANO
item.media:description: Interstate 80 in Vacaville, Calif., after a big-rig truck crashed and coated eastbound lanes in tomatoes.

item.title: Burnout vs Depression: How to Tell the Difference and Find Relief
item.description: Clinicians and researchers offer advice on how to tell the difference, and what to do about both.
item.dc:creator: Dani Blum
item.media:credit: Eric Helgas for The New York Times

item.title: What Is Quiet Quitting and Who Is It For?
item.description: For those not ready to make a grand exit, a softer approach may work.
item.dc:creator: Alyson Krueger
item.media:credit: Anthony Redpath – Getty Images

item.title: Work Burnout: How to Spot Symptoms and What to Do
item.description: Here’s how to recognize the physical symptoms of work-related stress — and what to do about them.
item.dc:creator: Melinda Wenner Moyer
item.media:credit: Alva Skog

item.title: How to Beat Burnout — Without Quitting Your Job
item.description: We’re all feeling a little fried at work and home. But there are ways to stay sharp and recharge.
item.dc:creator: Catherine Zuckerman
item.media:credit: Tim Peacock

item.title: New Curator at Victoria & Albert Museum Comes From a Jewelry Background
item.description: Emefa Cole first exhibited her bold, sculptural jewelry at a craft fair. Now she’s taking on a new role at the Victoria & Albert Museum in London.
item.dc:creator: Annabel Davidson
item.media:credit: Serena Brown for The New York Times
item.media:description: Emefa Cole on the steps of the Victoria & Albert Museum. She is the museum’s first curator of jewelry for the diaspora.
